pages.text:
Renaissance Theatre Company
A new non-profit theatre company dedicated to creating and developing original theatrical experiences in Orlando and beyond, with intentional focus on fair pay for artists, highlighting diverse perspectives, environmental sustainability, and creating Theatre in new and innovative ways.
We incorporated on February 18, 2021, and our first production together,
Oscar Wilde and Jesus Christ Walk Into a Gay Bar
, premiered at the Orlando Fringe Festival in May 2021.
Next, we surprised our local theatre friends by announcing that we’d acquired a new space, a two-story warehouse at Princeton St & McRae Ave, and opening the first version of our original vampire experience
Nosferatu
in October 2021, exactly three weeks after closing on the building. Our friends call it “the Ren.”
Since then, we’ve been going fast, making lots of new art, and creating lots of new jobs. We opened more original shows, helped our friends find space, and produced a strong slate of weekly events celebrating worthwhile communities.
Check out our Shows page to see a  list we’re very proud of.
View fullsize
A cute photo from our first show at Fringe in 2021. That was at the Shakes, so, not our theatre though :)
View fullsize
Okay this is us. For
Lenox Ave
, we just removed the wall at the top of this photo, leaving the old studs. Perks of having your own space!
Our board
Donald Rupe

Board of Directors
Jake Teixeira
Board of Directors
Thank you to Jason M. Bailey for his service as a founding member of the Board of Directors.
Our staff:
Renaissance Theatre Company has hired hundreds of artists so far. It’s one of our rules. (The always paying people thing.) For the latest look at who’s making art at the Ren, check out a program to one of our shows. Here are some of our recent credits for
Boots
and
Hair
.
Handy company information:
Renaissance Theatre Company, Inc. is a
501(c)(3)
public charity with status recognized back to our founding.
Our federal tax ID (EIN) is
86-2197367
.
(click to copy!)
You can check our non-profit status and download federal documents using the IRS’s
Tax Exempt Organization Search
tool.
Here is a copy of our determination letter.
At the state level, we are a “Florida non-profit corporation,” and you can look up our company filings using document number
N21000001860
.
Some public documents, like copies of other non-profit filings (Forms 990, 1023, and so on) will be posted on the site soon. Until then, please feel free to email
hello@rentheatre.com
to request anything.
Our Florida Department of Agriculture & Consumer Services Registration Number is
CH66046
. As the old saying goes,
A COPY OF THE OFFICIAL REGISTRATION AND FINANCIAL INFORMATION MAY BE OBTAINED FROM THE DIVISION OF CONSUMER SERVICES BY CALLING TOLL-FREE (800-435-7352) WITHIN THE STATE. REGISTRATION DOES NOT IMPLY ENDORSEMENT, APPROVAL, OR RECOMMENDATION BY THE STATE.

415 E Princeton St
Proudly from Orlando, FL
Original graphics by Landon St. Gordon
Website by Chris, Galvin, and Landon
For box office/tickets help, send us an email!
hello@rentheatre.com
If you need anything else or want to give us money, email Donald:
rupedon@gmail.com
For rental inquiries, email Bekah and Donald:
hello@rentheatre.com

Vive la résistance.
Sep 6
Written By
Chris Kampmeier
We posted this on our social media on September 6, 2021.
Happy Labor Day! This is your PSA that today is a celebration among workers who organize to provide mutual aid and solidarity in the face of the abuses of late capitalism, especially in Central Florida’s entertainment culture.
At the Ren:
We pay people for the work they do, and we pay on time.
We always pay at least what we consider to be a bare-minimum living wage, $15/hour.
We actively discourage a culture of tiredness, overwork, stress, and burnout, for all employees, including ourselves.
We value time off. It’s a part of your compensation, and we encourage our people to enjoy theirs. We try to structure our teams so you don’t have to follow a bunch of unnecessary rules about when you’re allowed to use the time you’ve earned.
We won’t abuse you by “hiring” you as an “independent contractor” unless that’s best for you. Instead, our people can work as normal W-2 employees. It costs us more, but you’re covered by our workers’ compensation insurance, and get other basic benefits like family/medical leave and unemployment coverage. It also makes your taxes easier at the end of the year.
We prioritize the health of our people, and we require vaccination against COVID-19 to work for us or to attend our events.
We’re a new company with a lot to figure out. There’s a lot more we have to do to protect each other. But we think this is a good start.
Chris Kampmeier
Previous
Previous
Welcome to the Ren, Orlando Fringe Festival!
Next
Next
A vaccination policy.
